Tucson takes a brave stance as the four large shapes come near him.  There =
would be no scaring him off as he stomps a foot down hard with a loud growl=
 and a snarl on his muzzle.  He meant business.  He was going to protect th=
e jungle come what may.   Yet there were a few curious animals who did seem=
 comfortable having him there.  One of them being a falcon, and a cougar.  =
They clear the area to give Tucson room to assert his dominance among the j=
ungle creatures.  

" Don't worry, I will protect you and your jungle.  No =
hand will lay harm here, I assure you."

He gives a loud warning roar to th=
e approaching figures.

Perpetually on the move and constantly busy. 

On A=
ug 31, 2011, at 2:23 PM, Super Cyclonus <supercyclonus@...> wrote:

>=
 > <OLD>
> >
> > There was a definite look of authority in his expression, =
as it was in the
> > nature of the dragon to be a highly territorial creatu=
re. In his spark, he
> > could sense the old dragon's soul, and can underst=
and that he at one time,
> > must have done his best to keep ecological har=
mony in the jungle. Due to
> > his failing health he was unable to maintain=
 his authority, and so chaos
> > seemed to take the place of whatever balan=
ce the old dragon maintained. But
> > that would change. The soul of the dr=
agon is now Tucson's to keep. So now
> > he had another commitment to keep,=
 he had to promise to keep the harmony and
> > rid the jungle of chaos, as =
was the dragon's personal vow years ago. That
> > vow was now Tucson's. So =
with a heavy thrust of his left front limb, he
> > firmly puts his taloned =
foot down and gives a territorial roar. Come what
> > may he was going to r=
escue his comrades and win back what was stolen from
> > Old Earth. There w=
as no mistake, the Silver Dragon had returned to claim his
> > place as the=
 Jungle Guardian.
> 
> <NEW>
> 
> As the jungled reverberated with TUSCON's=
 deep throated roar, birds of
> all types spooked and rose into the air mak=
ing all kinds of racket!
> Ancient forms of monkeys and other assorted tree=
 dwelling animals took
> to flight as well raising a din of their own. They=
 moved swiftly
> aloong branches and tree limbs as the trees themselves sho=
ok and
> rattled leaves vibrated and fell to the ground!
> 
> TUSCON's sona=
r while good at the very short distance did not avail him
> much as they sp=
read out. With all the trees and underbrush it was like
> a human trying to=
 peek into a house with the blinds closed, but in
> this case the blinds we=
re spread out several feet across. Even though
> you could see past some of=
 them, as the distance increase even
> TUSCON's sonar was obscured.
> 
> Ho=
wever one thing he did pick up was four large shapes moving towards
> him, =
each of them fully as large as he was! While his sonar was not as
> adept a=
s it once was, his enhanced senses were also helping him as
> they picked u=
p the loud crashing sounds of footsteps of the creatures
> as they approach=
ed him and trees cracking and bending as they passed
> by them.
> 
> TUSCON=
 was still standing at the edge of the clearing, the terminated
> sweep sti=
ll at his feet, the lubricant leakage had finally stopped.
> The shapes wer=
e coming from further into the jungle, they were perhaps
> several hundred =
yards away. It was only because of their size and the
> fact that they were=
 taking no precautions to hide their approach that
> he could detect them a=
t this distance. They were moving straight in
> TUSCON's direction.
> 
> (T=
AG)

<html><body bgcolor=3D"#FFFFFF"><div>Tucson takes a brave stance as the fou=
r large shapes come near him.  There would be no scaring him off as he=
 stomps a foot down hard with a loud growl and a snarl on his muzzle. &nbsp=
;He meant business.  He was going to protect the jungle come what may.=
   Yet there were a few curious animals who did seem comfortable havin=
g him there.  One of them being a falcon, and a cougar.  They cle=
ar the area to give Tucson room to assert his dominance among the jungle cr=
eatures.  </div><div><br></div><div>" Don't worry, I will protect you =
and your jungle.  No hand will lay harm here, I assure you."</div><div=
><br></div><div>He gives a loud warning roar to the approaching figures.<br=

> There was a definite look of authority in his expression, a=
s it was in the<br>
> nature of the dragon to be a highly territorial cr=
eature.  In his spark, he<br>
> could sense the old dragon's soul, and c=
an understand that he at one time,<br>
> must have done his best to keep=
 ecological harmony in the jungle.  Due to<br>
> his failing health he w=
as unable to maintain his authority, and so chaos<br>
> seemed to take t=
he place of whatever balance the old dragon maintained.  But<br>
> that =
would change.  The soul of the dragon is now Tucson's to keep.  So now<br>
=
> he had another commitment to keep, he had to promise to keep the harmo=
ny and<br>
> rid the jungle of chaos, as was the dragon's personal vow y=
ears ago.  That<br>
> vow was now Tucson's.  So with a heavy thrust of h=
is left front limb, he<br>
> firmly puts his taloned foot down and gives=
 a territorial roar.  Come what<br>
> may he was going to rescue his com=
rades and win back what was stolen from<br>
> Old Earth. There was no mi=
stake, the Silver Dragon had returned to claim his<br>
> place as the Ju=
ngle Guardian.<br>
<br>
<NEW><br>
<br>
As the jungled reverberated wi=
th TUSCON's deep throated roar, birds of<br>
all types spooked and rose int=
o the air making all kinds of racket!<br>
Ancient forms of monkeys and othe=
r assorted tree dwelling animals took<br>
to flight as well raising a din o=
f their own. They moved swiftly<br>
aloong branches and tree limbs as the t=
rees themselves shook and<br>
rattled leaves vibrated and fell to the groun=
d!<br>
<br>
TUSCON's sonar while good at the very short distance did not av=
ail him<br>
much as they spread out. With all the trees and underbrush it w=
as like<br>
a human trying to peek into a house with the blinds closed, but=
 in<br>
this case the blinds were spread out several feet across. Even thou=
gh<br>
you could see past some of them, as the distance increase even<br>
T=
USCON's sonar was obscured.<br>
<br>
However one thing he did pick up was f=
our large shapes moving towards<br>
him, each of them fully as large as he =
was! While his sonar was not as<br>
adept as it once was, his enhanced sens=
es were also helping him as<br>
they picked up the loud crashing sounds of =
footsteps of the creatures<br>
as they approached him and trees cracking an=
d bending as they passed<br>
by them.<br>
<br>
TUSCON was still standing at=
 the edge of the clearing, the terminated<br>
sweep still at his feet, the =
lubricant leakage had finally stopped.<br>
The shapes were coming from furt=
her into the jungle, they were perhaps<br>
several hundred yards away. It w=
as only because of their size and the<br>
fact that they were taking no pre=
cautions to hide their approach that<br>
he could detect them at this dista=
nce. They were moving straight in<br>
TUSCON's direction.<br>
